title: Who actually are the underdogs for the Tour de France?
content:

Who actually are the underdogs for the Tour de France?

The Tour de France is getting ever closer. Jonas Vingegaard of Visma-Lease a Bike will be aiming for a third consecutive maillot jaune despite injuries sustained in a crash at the Itzulia Basque Country earlier this season. UAE Team Emirates’ Tadej Pogačar, meanwhile, is aiming to return to the top step with a highly impressive Giro d’Italia performance in his legs.

Both team’s managers are taking the opportunity to play down their rider’s chances, claiming the other as the clear favourite and positioning their own as underdog.

But can we really be calling back-to-back Tour de France winner Vingegaard an underdog? Can a man who just dominated the Giro at a canter be anything but a favourite?

Below, we’ve assessed the pair’s chances, along with the other top names, to try to figure out who the underdogs of the 2024 Tour de France actually are.

Underdog contender 1: Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates)

Two Tour de France victories and Giro d’Italia dominance does not an underdog make. But UAE Team Emirates Manager Maxtin Joxean Fernandez pointed the finger at rival Vingegaard as being top billing at the Tour de France, saying in an interview with Sporza that ‘Pogačar was fatigued after the Giro d’Italia’ and that Vingegaard is ‘the big favourite’, having been training at altitude for several weeks.

It’s understandable that three weeks at maximum effort in a Grand Tour would exhaust anyone, let alone someone aiming to win their first Tour de France title since 2021. In May, Pogačar won the Giro d’Italia on his debut with relative ease, as expected, with his closest competitor Dani Martínez (Bora-Hansgrohe) finishing almost ten minutes behind.

Even if he’s Giro-fatigued, the Slovenian star can still rely on the strongest team in the peloton. Adam Yates and João Almeida dominated the recent Tour de Suisse, winning two stages apiece and finishing first and second on GC. Both will be riding in support of Pogačar at the Tour alongside a line-up of top-notch talent that also includes 21-year-old super-talent Juan Ayuso.

The last man to complete the Giro/Tour double was Marco Pantani in 1998. If anyone could achieve this feat in the current peloton, it’s Pogačar, or this guy…

  • Underdog ranking: 0/5

Underdog contender 2: Jonas Vingegaard (Visma-Lease a Bike)

Jonas Vingegaard has won the last two editions of the Tour de France. However, the Dane broke his collarbone and ribs and suffered a punctured lung in a horrible crash at Itzulia Basque Country in April. It’s understandable that this has derailed his preparations for a yellow jersey defence.

Visma-Lease a Bike said that it took a month before Vingegaard was riding again, announcing his return with a video on social media, in which Vingegaard said, ‘This is the first time back on the bike for me, riding outside, and it’s really nice to finally be able to ride like normal again. To finally be able to ride on the road has been amazing. I’m really looking forward to taking the next steps’.

He was pictured at the team’s last altitude training camp before the start of the Tour alongside most of his teammates for the race in Wout van Aert, Christophe Laporte, Tiesj Benoot, Jan Tratnik and Matteo Jorgenson.

It’s a mighty squad, as usual, and should he be either not at full fitness or just suffering, they have the strength of 2023 Vuelta a España winner Sepp Kuss and the increasingly impressive Matteo Jorgenson – who won Paris-Nice and came second at the Dauphiné – in their ranks should they need another option in the GC battle.

  • Underdog ranking: 1/5

Underdog contender 3: Primož Roglič (Bora-Hansgrohe)

This will be Primož Roglič’s first Tour de France with his new Bora-Hansgrohe team, which packs some firepower in super-domestiques Jai Hindley and Aleksandr Vlasov. Roglič has plenty of experience in winning Grand Tours, having tucked away three consecutive Vuelta a España titles and a Giro d’Italia maglia rosa. But the Tour de France is the one that has evaded him. 

Roglič finished just off the podium in 2018. In 2020, he lost the yellow jersey on a dramatic final day of racing as Pogačar claimed the top spot after a dominant time-trial display on La Planche des Belles Filles. In both 2021 and 2022 he abandoned through injuries sustained after crashing. 

If he manages to avoid hitting the ground this year (and it’s a big ‘if’, he was another caught up in the Itzulia crash that took Vingegaard out), Roglič should be able to maintain a strong place on GC. Especially considering he’s already won the warm-up in the Critérium du Dauphiné. 

  • Underdog ranking: 2/5

Underdog contender 4: Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep)

Remco Evenepoel completes the ‘big four’ of favourites despite this being his first outing on the Tour de France rollercoaster. Yet the 24-year-old is no newcomer, he already has the palmarès of a seasoned vet. 

The two-times World Champion won the 2022 Vuelta a España at just 22 years of age. Given Belgium’s rich legacy in cycling, the expectations on Evenepoel’s shoulders are huge, with the country looking to celebrate its first Tour winner since Lucien Van Impe in 1976. 

Evenepoel will undoubtedly be one to watch. He said in December last year that state his aim was to make it to the ‘top 5’, but since he came down hard in the Itzulia crash there will surely be less pressure for a big result here. This is scheduled to be his only Grand Tour of the season though, providing good reason to go all out. He’ll certainly be a favourite for the time-trials.

  • Underdog ranking: 3/5

Underdog contender 5: Carlos Rodríguez (Ineos Grenadiers)

On to the actual underdogs now; dismiss Carlos Rodríguez at your peril. The 23-year-old placed 5th at last year’s Tour de France, which earned him a ‘revelation’ title, as did his impressive victory on Stage 14 – the hectic mountain stage that saw motorbikes hold up a Pogačar attack.

He has been flying this season too, winning his first WorldTour stage race in the Tour de Romandie as his development continues. A Tour de France podium is calling his name and the Ineos Grenadiers team, including former winners Egan Bernal and Geraint Thomas, will surely be a big help to get him there.

  • Underdog ranking: 4/5

Underdog contender 6: Simon Yates (Jayco-AlUla)

This might be the last time Simon Yates has a direct shot at the Tour de France GC, with rumours that he may be riding for Visma-Lease a Bike in 2025, where leadership will be hard to fight for. 

Yates won the 2019 Vuelta a España ahead of Enric Mas (Movistar), holding the jersey for the majority of the race. His best result at the Tour de France came in 2023, where he finished just off the podium behind his twin brother Adam (UAE Team Emirates). 

But for this year, Jayco-AlUla’s sports director Tristan Hoffman said to Dutch website In de Leiderstrui, ‘A stage victory in the Tour can be just as important as, for example, finishing fifth [overall]… let’s just present both options to him… reaching the podium will be very difficult.’

Yates is a determined stage hunter, having already won in all three Grand Tours, his most successful being the Giro d’Italia, so this might be his true target. As for a GC battle, we’ll see how that goes. 

  • Underdog ranking: 5/5

Underdog contender 7: Richard Carapaz (EF Education-EasyPost)

Olympic champion Richard Carapaz was forced to abandon the recent Tour de Suisse but is still focussed on the Tour de France. Fortunately the injuries sustained in a crash on Stage 4 in Switzerland were not severe and the move was said to be taken as more of a precaution. 

Carapaz became the first Ecuadorian cyclist to win the Giro d’Italia in 2019 while racing for Movistar. He shone towards the end of the second week particularly, thriving on the mountain slopes and claiming victory on Stage 14, which allowed him to pull the maglia rosa onto his shoulders and never let it go.

The EF Education-EasyPost team are one that can be found lighting up races and are perhaps more suited to stage hunting than having a focus on the yellow jersey. But when needed to help Carapaz on GC, you can be sure they’ve got the talent to try. It’s finding the balance between helping Carapaz and stage hunting that will be key for the team this July.

  • Underdog ranking: 5/5

Underdog contender 8: Enric Mas (Movistar)

In the past, Movistar has made the mistake of having too many leaders at a Grand Tour, who ended up cancelling each other out. This year Enric Mas will be Movistar’s sole leader at the Tour de France. Despite never reaching the top step of the podium, Mas has thrice finished in second at his home Grand Tour of the Vuelta a España. 

It never seems to click for Mas at the Tour; his best-placed result is 5th at the 2020 edition, while his last two have been DNFs. In 2022 he was forced to abandon before Stage 19 with Covid and in 2023 he broke his shoulder after crashing on the opening stage.

Looking at results in stage races this season, Mas has finished fifth at the Volta a Catalunya, sixth at the Tour de Romandie and seventh at the Tour de Suisse. It’s hard to see a jump to the yellow jersey, but on his day Mas is still entertaining to watch – he possesses a die-hard spirit on the bike, battling to the finish no matter what.

  • Underdog ranking: 5/5
